subsection_content_4: Two additional outbreaks in poultry farms have been detected less than a week after H5N1 was first found in Ghana.  Dr. Darlington Owusi, the head of the Avian Influenza Surveillance team, said that several crates of eggs and about 500 birds have been destroyed at one site. He suggested that the virus may have spread from a nearby poultry farm where 12,000 birds, 323 crates of eggs and 375 kilos of feed have been destroyed. Details on the H5N1 testing in both cases have not been released at this time. (
subsection_content_3: During the past week, H5N1 outbreaks have been reported in several regions in the country. Some 8500 chickens were culled in three farms in the Savar region; a farm in the Mirpur area in the capital city of Dhaka had tested positive, and a farm in the Magura district, 200 km to the southwest of the capital, was also infected. In all, Bangladesh has culled 132,000 chickens in 52 farms since the outbreaks began in March.
subsection_content_2: The Department of Interior was quoted by the Reuters news agency this week saying that it will test 27,000 wild bird samples in 2007. In the same report, the Department of Agriculture stated that it will test fewer birds than it did in 2006, about 77,000 samples.
